reviews.review_msg: He is honestly not a great prof and he will brag about it! He marks based off of what he thinks is right, not if the paper is actually well written. His feedback is not great, his lectures are go with the flow (even though there is an exam), and his grading criteria is MIA. He also just will not teach you anything so do not expect to learn.

His classes are funny and engaging- he's clearly super knowledgeable and goes on many tangents without being pretentious. Attendance and participation is important. He's one of the very few English profs at SFU that values and welcomes disagreement, and does not expect students to blindly adopt his ideologies. Values good arguments.
Jon Smith is one of the best English professors at SFU in my opinion. Write a solid essay and you'll get solid feeback. His lectures are enjoyable and he's knowledgeable about what he teaches.

I loved Jon's lectures because he is so knowledgeable about American history and made everything very digestible with humour and anecdotes. Very straightforward essays and final exam. 5 required texts, but they were all super interesting! Show up and take good notes and you will be good!

Jon is one of the best lecturers I've ever had the privilege of listening to. Surprisingly, he doesn't like the lecture format himself, but he's an incredible speaker. His lectures were incredibly insightful and invaluable when it came to studying alone. He really knows his stuff and I hope I will get to take another course with him.

Jon  is an awesome prof. His exams  while not easy, are very passable as long as you attend lecture and focus on textual evidence of the close readings he gives. I also had an amazing TA (shoutout Belle), which while unfortunate your TA definitely dictates how well/ how much you like the class. Jon is so great that I'm taking another of his classes

Easily one of the best profs I've had. Super great prof and even better person, really fun and caring. Heavy reading load and class is discussion based so make sure to be caught up on your readings. Super fair grader!

Lectures were hard to follow, hard to pinpoint the most important things. Enjoyed his enthusiasm, good with letting everyone speak if desired. Reading pace is fast (too fast IMO) but I loved the book selection. Easy grader from my experience, straightforward midterm (final tbd). He wouldn't be my first choice but I would still take his class again!

Jon was one of the coolest profs I've taken, especially considering it was my first English course at SFU. The books were amazing, TAs were amazing, and Jon was always willing to converse. I'm taking another course of his this semester, and I know I won't regret it. Take one of his courses if you get the chance!
I really enjoyed Jon's lecturing style however I found it quite difficult to keep up with how much we had to read considering a full course load.

If I could take this course again, I absolutely would. Jon is an amazing prof and especially for someone just starting off at SFU, this course was so much fun. He also encourages discussion and participation which is really helpful when understanding various texts. You won't regret taking this course!

Comes off as simultaneously kind and rude (tough front but a nice guy). Reasonable prof. You have to put in work for the readings but hey, it's an English class. Worst part about him as a prof is that he talks quickly about many different things (hard to keep up with), and lectures aren't recorded. But I liked the course and am glad I took it.

Jon is a pretty decent prof. He kept the midterm and final to content he mentioned in lecture so attending them and taking notes while you're there is important. The paper was also not that difficult. My hand hurt after all the writing for the final but at least he handed out timbits every hour of it lol.

It was a horrible final exam. Level of difficulty is ridiculously high for 1st year course. Easy miderm. He does not post anything.. i mean anything on canvas. Not even the assignment rubric. Good luck.

Jon is an amazing prof, he cares about his students getting enough information for exams. Satanic verses was a hard read, even for those who read a lot. The thing i hate is that you can end up with a terrible TA. My TA was incredibly rude to people in the class (not Jon's fault but just a heads up). Don't take if you hate participating.

Professor Smith is engaging. The course is heavily based on the lectures so make sure you pay attention to the specific passages that he mentions. as for tutorials, I personally think that everything is fairly marked. the readings are heavy and boring, however if you pay attention in the lectures, they aren't too important. tests are easy.

Jon is a guy who well-respects his students, and you can clearly tell he just wants whats best for you. However, he sometimes gets distracted by random topics that he may think are relevant to his lecture. He's got some good humour if you're into dry humour, and he makes class entertaining. But lectures are mandatory because the exams are lec based
he's so boringggg!!! does not post anything on canvas so if you miss a class good luck for the essays. Midterms easy but marks are ridiculously hard for a first-year course. He acts very entitled

I really enjoy his lecture most of the time, but he's definitely extremely pretentious. Thinks very highly of himself, and doesn't hesitate to impose his superiority over his first year classes. 
Might be better for this guy to stick to teaching higher level classes, because those students maybe he would view as real, intelligent, people.

Dr. Smith was a delight! I took his class on Popular Literature and Culture, with a focus on the TV Show Buffy the Vampire Slayer). Dr. Smith is a passionate professor and made a 4-hour evening seminar quite enjoyable and insightful. As someone who is not an English major, I deeply valued his feedback on my papers, although his comments were blunt.

Jon is an incredible professor. He truly cares about his students and does everything in his capacity to improve their writing skills and their critical thinking skills. His lectures are participation heavy and if this makes you anxious, I suggest avoiding seminar classes because they are formulated to push you out of your comfort zone :)

Professor Smith truly cares about student learning. If you are uncomfortable speaking up in class, reconsider if a upper division seminar style class is for you. He was skilled at fostering discussion and encouraged participation. If you want to improve your writing, take this class! The readings were heavy, but excellent. I learned a lot.

The class was very reading and participation-heavy, but that's to be expected in an upper division seminar course. Jon always had great insights to add to discussion, and I found him to be a very fair marker with good feedback.

Dr. Smith is an incredibly witty, nice, admirable, and self-aware professor! He really cares about his students. He might be a bit of a tough marker, but he genuinely wants to help his people improve their critical thinking and essay writing. I also loved most of the readings in the course and thought his grading scheme was generous.

Extremely hard marker. He is also super aware of who is participating and who isn't. Also takes attendance very seriously, so try not to miss classes, he WILL pick on you if you do not speak in class which gave me a lot of anxiety. Overall I'm not a fan of him, he also will pay attention to who read the books and who didn't.

Jon is an amazing professor. He clearly cares about his students and really challenges them to learn the course material. While the reading load can be a bit heavy, it is still manageable and an acceptable workload for a 400-level English class. He also selects very interesting and relevant texts, so that helps. Very fair marker.

If you are willing to do the readings and participate in class you will have a great experience. Jon's classes challenge you in a way that will have you appreciating everything in hindsight. It was sometimes a struggle to keep up with the readings amid work and a full course load, but it was definitely manageable. I 100% recommend Jon as a prof.

All you have to do is do the readings. His classes are set up in a way that you will do just fine if you read the course material and attend class. I actually think he is a very generous marker and gives very helpful feedback on your writing. There is a lot of reading and if you fall behind it sucks. Paper proposal can also set you up for success.
Take his class. Love the guy.
lowkey a jerk

I took ENGL 437 "Seminar in American Literatures" with Jon at SFU. One time, 3/4 of the class didnt do the reading and he got really mad. He yelled at the class "DO THE F****** READINGS!!" . Jon is arrogant and embodies the big-brained prof stereotype. Take his course for the credit, he's also an easy marker, but character-wise -- poor.

Jon is one of the best professors I've had at SFU. His lectures shouldn't be missed, as the amount of supplementary content he provides on the novels can change the way you read them. Very understanding if one or two classes need to be missed, and his use of student-provided discussion questions allows for plenty of peer-discussion.

Jon is a stand-up prof. He has so many big ideas that sparked great class discussions. He can be a bit abrupt at times but never in a mean way, he's actually really funny. I felt like a lot of my classmates were too smart for me but Jon validated and listened to every one of my ideas and suggestions. One of the best in the English department.

Professor Smith is definitely a good prof, but not because he's nice to you. He's very funny, but the reason he's such an excellent prof is that he genuinely works towards teaching students applicable skills rather than handing them answers and analysis. Thus, you will receive lower grades than usual, because he will make you show those skills off.

Knows the material but his presentation leaves a lot to be desired. Unprepared for class, lectures all over the place, constantly losing the thread or forgetting what he had taught us, lackadaisical attitude towards lecturing, unrealistic grading expectations. Kind of a narcissist; invited a guest lecturer twice and then talked over her. Tiresome.
A bit sporadic and tends to digress, but all in all a he knows his stuff and does his best

Jon is a nice prof, but he is a bit tough on the grading scale. Seems to be a bit of a tough grader and very very attendance focused. He keeps lectures fun and entertaining and the readings are really great, just a lot of them. You have to attend them or you will get a deduction on your grade so be aware of this.

Hard to get higher than an A- in my opinion. I'm no award-winning writer, but I took another English course and found the grading to be easier. I have to give Jon credit where it's due though because I did learn a hell of a lot in his class!

Jon is engaging during lectures and tries to add humour to it. He does his best answering questions that students have. He posts additional material on canvas but no review material. Make sure to go to every class because theres a good chance a passage mentioned will be on the exam. Some topics were too difficult for a first year course.

I used to love english, but repeated bad essays & highschool teachers made me hate it. I was super sceptical of the "american lit" stuff but he connected it to history, academic culture, and society to keep it related to everyone no matter your major. Reading and lectures are mandatory obvs, its no harder than any actually good english class

very very unorganized and can not seem to keep a thought going start to finish. clearly knows a lot about his material and likes to act like he is amazing because he is so much smarter then first years in an entry english class.

Jon is awesome, his class was actually very engaging despite his lack of slides and he is hilarious! I would recommend going to class as he does a very good job of explaining the readings if you are confused! Jon's classes are a MUST take at SFU! :)

Jon was great. He made you work for your grade, but if you attended class and followed what he wanted you to watch/read, the tasks were super easy. What I liked about him was that he was personable both in the classroom and during office hours. He wants to see his students succeed so pushes them. Take his class if you really wanna delve into lit.
Loved the material put together for this class. Included books And movies. Really enjoyed it. Very passionate about his teaching. Gave Very good clues as to what would be on the final.

Jon is extremely passionate about Southern Literature, and I am sure I would be if I actually got to read any. This class was extremely unorganized and I often missed readings because I was unaware he had assigned them because he would email and update canvas and it was extremely confusing. Nice guy, could be a good teacher
WWJD, "What would Jon do?" I ask myself this before every major and minor events of my day. Jon truly is the wind beneath my winds. Beneath all of our winds....
I found that he tried harder to be funny and edgy than to provide anything of educational merit in his lectures. Stay away from this guy.
Don't take a class with this prof. He is an unorganized jerk.

ENGL 104 studies nonfiction, so if you hate nonfiction, don't take it.  I'm enjoyed this english class because it taught me new skills and I learned a lot of interesting things.  Attend all the tutorials cause they're worth a chunk of your mark. One tip: note down all the quotes and significance he talks about cause they'll be in the final.

As far as quality professors go, Jon ranks among the best. He has a vast knowledge of his field and is able to take a natural approach to teaching. This involves occasionally going on "rants", but he keeps class lectures entertaining and informative. I would reccomend him to students willing to work hard, and improve in this subject.

Although I heard great things about him before taking the course I can't say I was satisfied. He made jokes here and there but generally lectures were boring. The material was brutally hard and focused around American politics. He might be funny, but the class was terrible and pointless.
Great Prof. Very interesting and keeps lectures interesting. Would take another English course with him!

Great Prof. Only class I actually looked forward to in the mornings. Great group discussion and I really enjoyed Jon's upbeat, occasionally sarcastic personality. Not an easy prof but definitely rewards effort. I 100% recommend him!

Jon Smith managed to make political rhetoric fun and engaging and I loved going to this class. He also made sure to prepare us for the final exam to an extent I've rarely seen in 300-level courses, which I appreciated. I would highly recommend both the course and the professor.

Enjoy going to class and listening to his rants. Takes a 'tough coach' method to teaching and although some material is hard to get through, the class itself is interesting and made me want to take another english course with him!

He is really funny, but I do not really get much out of the class... yes he goes over the books, but I feel like I will have no use for what he tells me... Still, not a bad class, and I actually do not mind attending.
Is Jon Smith a hero? Yes.
I look forward to every class with this man. He completes me, and I him.

It's only a few weeks into term, and people are already complaining about Dr. Smith's lack of organization. Frankly, I love that he's not one of those Professors who comes to class with the same slides and notes that he's been using for ten years, and will keep using until he retires. Smith's spontaneous style is what makes this class so much fun.

This class kept me alive Summer semester. Sure, it was tough as h*ll and Smith doesn't give away marks for free -- you seriously have to earn your grade. But the persona he's created for teaching (which is clearly an act) is hilarious, and as long as you don't have thin skin, you'll appreciate his biting humor.

Dr. Smith genuinely cares about his students and he marks fair. His weakest point is his teaching. Despite having demonstrated a few times that he has the potential to teach better, most of  his lectures are poorly organized. As the course is very difficult, excellent organization is a must. I appreciate his unique personality and sense of humor.

Jon is one of the most consistenly entertaining profs I've had at SFU. He's ridiculously knowledgable and good at creating dialogue. He also has a very funny sarcastic sense of humour that, unfortunately, seemed to irritate those with entitlement complexes. Worth taking for sure.

Good teacher but places unfair expectations on students with reading and assignments.  The ?short papers? require a lot of time and effort.  Be prepared to waste hours of time reading a lot of gibberish.  This course was twice the amount of work compared to my other 300 level English class.  I was most annoyed that while he expects a lot, he does n

He's a nice enough guy, but it often seems like he hasn't thought through his lectures beforehand, so sometimes they're tangential and dense. Even though it's a 4th year course, seminars are much more like lectures.

It was a difficult learning environment. He is very smart but bored by others who do not share his level of intelligence.  His lectures meander around the topic and constantly include anecdotes of his personal life.  He is insecure and constantly needs ego stroking.

Jon gets a pretty bad rap. For the most part, I think people have a hard time telling when he's joking and when he's not, and he plays with that a little bit. He's a tough, but rather fair marker. He demands a LOT of reading and discussion, but overall I didn't find that anything he was asking of us was extremely difficult or unusually picky.

He was engaging in class especially at 830 in the morning, his essay topics were pretty tough though, lectures are definitely helpful as long as you keep up in the reading the class is pretty manageable i'd definitely take him again.

This was a great class and the prof was excellent.  Smith is an engaging lecturer and has a positive and helpful attitude towards his students.  The class is a lot of work but its worth the effort.  Smith is the best instructor I have ever had.

This was a great class and the prof was excellent.  Smith is an engaging lecturer and has a positive and helpful attitude towards his students.  The class is a lot of work but its worth the effort.  Smith is the best instructor I?ve ever had.
